titleStmt.title: England's Ichabod, glory departed, discoursed by two Christian men, zealous for the glory of God, and true lovers of their nation: the one called Heraclitus junior, weeping for and lamenting the inevitable wo and desolation impending and approaching on his native country. And the other called Democritus natu minimus, laughing at the ignorance, blindness, madness, and inexorable stupidity of his own nation, overwhelmed in folly, sin, and wickedness, insensible of its own ruine and misery. Both of them paradoxically praising the Jesuites, and their spurious seed, for their policie, activitie, and dexteritie, in promoting their factions and projects. / By Heraclitus junior, and Democritus natu minimus, for Ri: Fosterschism.
titleStmt.author: Heraclitus junior.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 30 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 8 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

This Phase I text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal. The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

titleStmt.title: England's Ichabod, glory departed, discoursed by two Christian men, zealous for the glory of God, and true lovers of their nation: the one called Heraclitus junior, weeping for and lamenting the inevitable wo and desolation impending and approaching on his native country. And the other called Democritus natu minimus, laughing at the ignorance, blindness, madness, and inexorable stupidity of his own nation, overwhelmed in folly, sin, and wickedness, insensible of its own ruine and misery. Both of them paradoxically praising the Jesuites, and their spurious seed, for their policie, activitie, and dexteritie, in promoting their factions and projects. / By Heraclitus junior, and Democritus natu minimus, for Ri: Fosterschism.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: England's Ichabod, Glory departed, DISCOURSED By TWO CHRISTIAN MEN, zealous for the glory of GOD, and true Lovers of their NATION: The One Called HERACLITÆ²S junior, Weeping for and lamenting the inevitable Wo and DeÅ¿olation impending and approaching on his native Country. And the Other called DEMOCRITÆ²S natu minimus, Laughing at the Ignorance, BlindneÅ¿s, MadneÅ¿s, and inexorable Stupidity of his own Nation, overwhelmed in Folly, Sin, and WickedneÅ¿s, inÅ¿enÅ¿ible of its own Ruine and MiÅ¿ery. Both of them Paradoxically praiÅ¿ing the JESUITES, and their Å¿purious Å¿eed, for their Policie, Activitie, and Dexteritie, in promoting their Factions and Projects.
By Heraclitus junior, and Democritus natu minimus, for RI: FOSTERSCHISM.

q.hi: Wo to them that go down to Egypt for help, and Å¿tay on horÅ¿es, and truÅ¿t in chariots, becauÅ¿e they are many, and in horÅ¿e-men, becauÅ¿e they are very Å¿trong: but they look not to the holy One of IÅ¿rael, neither Å¿eek the Lord.

div.q: Every kingdom divided againÅ¿t it Å¿elf, is brought to deÅ¿olation; and every citie or houÅ¿e divided againÅ¿t it Å¿elf, Å¿hall not Å¿tand.

sp.speaker: Democritus.
sp.p: MY love and affection to you, moÅ¿t dear Heraclitus, hath induced me to viÅ¿it you, that you and I may diÅ¿courÅ¿e a little touching theÅ¿e woful and doleful days wherein we live.

sp.speaker: Heraclitus.
sp.p:
Welcome, my moÅ¿t cordial and moÅ¿t conÅ¿tant friend; I rejoyce in your preÅ¿ence Å¿o gladÅ¿ome to me, that, if any thing would aÅ¿Å¿wage my mournful tearsâª your chearful Å¿ociety would do it. But, Sir, it is too late: I rather wiÅ¿h to be diÅ¿Å¿olved into Tears, then to be revived with Mirth; for the glory of England is departed. Where is the glory of our Cities, of our Academies, of Trade, and MerchandiÅ¿e, either DomeÅ¿tick, or with Forrein Nations; of Equity, Law, and JuÅ¿tice; of the Liberty of the People; of the Freedom and Priviledges of the Nation in the whole Common-wealth? Nay, (which is the greateÅ¿t wo of all) where is the glory of Religion and Sincerity? Religion is nothing but Opus operatum, a formal, out-Å¿ide Preaching and Hearing, like the fig-tree curÅ¿ed by our Lord ChriÅ¿t, bearing no fruits
of Charity, Humility, Obedience, JuÅ¿tice and Mercy. It is by Å¿ome made a meer Å¿talking-horÅ¿e and a Å¿ervant to Pride, Ambition, CovetouÅ¿neÅ¿s; whoÅ¿e entire and endeared companions and confederates, gilded HypocriÅ¿ie, and execrable Villany, mercileÅ¿s Cruelty, bloody and horrid TreaÅ¿on, muÅ¿t be Å¿ometimes aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tant, to effect impious lawleÅ¿s deÅ¿ignes. And where will the glory of one of the moÅ¿t famous Cities of the world, of London, be, if the Citizens loÅ¿e Exportation of Cloth and Stuffs, and Importation of forrein MerchandiÅ¿es, as they have loÅ¿t themÅ¿elves in their Covenant made with God, whereof there is a Table and Copie, for memorial, fixed and hanged up in moÅ¿t Temples in the City? And then where will the glory of Clothiers, Artificers, and others, whoÅ¿e Trades and Livelihoods depend upon manufacture of Cloth and Stuffs, appear? And where will the glory of the Nobility and Gentry, whoÅ¿e revenues depend upon Sheep and Wool, Å¿oon after be? LaÅ¿t of all, where will the glory of our Army and Souldiery be, if they conquer not all Europe, or at leaÅ¿t quit themÅ¿elves againÅ¿t the Power and Forces thereof? For it appeareth manifeÅ¿tly, that they have provoked moÅ¿t part thereof to be enemies to our Nation. Woful will our Lamentations be: I Å¿hall not be able to weep enough: I Å¿hall even wiÅ¿h to be a Niobe, that I might be diÅ¿Å¿olved into tears. Tantum relligio potuit Å¿uadere malorum? as the Poet. Simon, John, Eleazar; Prelate, Independent, Presbyter. Scarce three men meet accidentally together of one minde: men are Å¿o tranÅ¿ported with fiery zeal for one of the three, and Å¿o void of meekneÅ¿s of Å¿pirit, that they become as fierce as Bellarmine, and cry down all Arguments on the behalf of the other two, although they be newly rouzed from the pillow of Bacchus, and be inÅ¿cient of the validity of what was or can be Å¿aid. Why hath Opinion, diÅ¿tracted about Rule and Government, brought theÅ¿e later evils upon us, Å¿ince the juÅ¿t Å¿hall live by Faith alone, and not by Government?

sp.speaker: Democritus.
sp.p:
I my Å¿elf making the Å¿ame obÅ¿ervations which you do, and being apprehenÅ¿ive of the Calamities and DeÅ¿olation neer approaching, and attending our Nation, could, as I am Å¿ubject to
natural paÅ¿Å¿ions, mourn and lament alÅ¿o: but Å¿ince I am fully Å¿atisfied, by conÅ¿ulting with the Å¿acred Prophets, that there is an inevitable Divine Decree in this vengeance of the Sword, fore-appointed for the accompliÅ¿hment and manifeÅ¿tation of God's infinite power and glory in purging his Church, and bringing in a better people, and in reÅ¿tauration of Mercy and JuÅ¿tice in the Common-wealth; that Grief, which would otherwiÅ¿e poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿s me, is turned into mirth. Yet, if it may be asked by Prayer, Let not, O God, the Parable and CurÅ¿e of Jotham (mentioned in the ninth Chapter of Judges) be fulfilled, and fall upon our Abimelechs and Shechemites of England! Hearken, ye men of Shechem, famous Citizens, that God may hearken unto you, and not Å¿end an evil Å¿pirit amongÅ¿t ye, to Å¿tir ye up to deÅ¿troy one another, as Abimele â¢ h did the Shechemites, when they had raiÅ¿ed him, and made him their King, after the bloody murder of his brethren, the legitimate Å¿ons of Gedeon, about Å¿eventy men. Like noble Bereans, read the Chapter, and apply it. And take notice of a few words uttered and predicted againÅ¿t our Nation, and Å¿ome famous Citie thereof, above 1100 yeers Å¿ince, in the Reign of Vortiger, printed at Frankfurt about 50 yeers Å¿ince: Viz. Vae perjuriae Genti, qua urbs inclyta propter eam ruet: FeÅ¿tinat namque dies qua cives ob Å¿celera perjurii peribunt. If that AÅ¿trologer who uttered theÅ¿e words, amongÅ¿t others, (whereof we have Å¿een the completion in a great part, and could, if without controulment permitted, fully demonÅ¿trate) did now live, he would laugh profuÅ¿ely at Å¿ome modern AÅ¿trologers, who gainÅ¿ay them, or Å¿peak Å¿lightly or dubiouÅ¿ly of them, although completed.

sp.speaker: Heraclitus.
sp.p: If there be a Divine Vengeance in this Å¿courge of DiviÅ¿ion, Faction, Rapine, and BloodÅ¿hedding; why have the people Å¿everally murmured, railed, and clamoured, Å¿ome againÅ¿t the beheaded King, Å¿ome againÅ¿t the Parliament, Å¿ome againÅ¿t the City of London, Å¿ome againÅ¿t the Scots, as the Å¿everal Å¿ole cauÅ¿es of our unnatural and bloody Civil War?

sp.speaker: Democritus.
sp.p:
BecauÅ¿e they ignorantly and falÅ¿ly conjecture that all things
come to paÅ¿s by Chance, without Divine providence and governance; many being Å¿o peremptory and Å¿tiff in Opinion, and Å¿o puffed up with their own tranÅ¿cendencie of Piety, and Singularity of Å¿pirit, that they explode all Opinions but their own, and all ReaÅ¿ons and Arguments againÅ¿t the Å¿ame, although valid and forcible; as is evident, in that, that though they deÅ¿piÅ¿e Government and all Dominion, yet none more eagerly aÅ¿pire to, and hunt after high places of Domination, both EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿tical and Temporal: And when they are inveÅ¿ted in them, none Å¿o rigid as ThemÅ¿elves, who Å¿o much cenÅ¿ured and condemned the Government of Others to be oppreÅ¿Å¿ive and tyrannical: And then they make oÅ¿tentation, and buz like the Fly upon the wheel, This have I done; whenas the coach-wheels and horÅ¿es heels Å¿tirred the duÅ¿t: So, by the help of InÅ¿inuation, and Å¿ubtil Faction, ambitious, covetous, proud BoaÅ¿ters, and Å¿ingular Self-lovers are exalted to trample on their brethren. Plurimis famam ã in non-Latin alphabet ã , avidÃ¨ magis ambientibus quÃ m fervidÃ¨, & Å¿incerÃ¨ ã in non-Latin alphabet ã annunciantibus. One would be Paul, another Cephas, and the third Apollo: and the itching-eared people love to have it Å¿o: But what will they do in the end? TheÅ¿e men conÅ¿ider not that their own particular Å¿ins, and the general Å¿ins of the Nation, have drawn down God's wrath and indignation againÅ¿t us; Å¿ome daring to call our Covenant made with God, filed of Record in our Temples An old Almanack, which may be thrown in the fire at yeers end.

sp.speaker: Heraclitus.
sp.p: How might their UnderÅ¿tandings be better informed, and their Judgements rectified?

sp.speaker: Democritus.
sp.p:
By none other means but, firÅ¿t, by reading the Scriptures, and principally the Prophet IÅ¿aiah, Chap. 45. verÅ¿. 7. and Amos, Chap. 3. v. 6. and Jerem. Chap. 25, v. 15, 16, 26, 27, 29, 31, 32. and Chap. 3. v. 6. and Chap. 30. v. 24. and Chap. 34. v. 15, 16, 17, 18, 19, 20. and Chap. 5. The whole Å¿cope of which two laÅ¿t-recited Chapters plainly parallel with our Times and Nation, and Matth. 24âª with divers other Scriptures, as well touching the neerneÅ¿s of the end of the world, in confutation of the Millenary
SchiÅ¿m, much availing for the Romane party, and now boldly and buÅ¿ily broached by Å¿ome of the prime DiÅ¿Å¿enting Brethren, Igodown, Oglethorp, and others; as alÅ¿o, touching National Churches, in confutation of Independencie and Singularity; as Rev. 20. 4. and 21. 24, 26. and IÅ¿ai. 60. 3, 5 10, 11, 16. and Rev. 11. 15. And Å¿econdly, by comparing the laÅ¿t occurrences of Tumults and InÅ¿urrections when we had a King, he then having no Councel nor Army; and our preÅ¿ent Home-diviÅ¿ions and Naumachies, with the beginnings of our Civil wars, when we had a King, he then having an HoÅ¿t of men, and Councel. But now, Å¿ince we have no King, who can be Å¿aid to be the cauÅ¿e of our preÅ¿ent broils, rapine, and Å¿poils, by Sea and Land, but our own Å¿ins; CÃ¹m Anglia laborat Å¿aevire in Å¿emetipÅ¿am? Even as when there was no King in IÅ¿rael, every man did that which was good in his own eyes: as Judg. 17. 6. and Ch. 19. more at large.

sp.speaker: Heraclitus.
sp.p:
The evidence thereof aggravateth my Å¿orrow, and increaÅ¿eth my tears; and much more, when I read the fourth verÅ¿e of the third Chapter of HoÅ¿ea, threatning judgement againÅ¿t the IÅ¿raelites, that they Å¿hould be many days without a King or Prince, &c. Was it a judgement in the days of IÅ¿rael, and is it none in our days? Our Laws have depended upon Monarchy, although enacted (which was our happineÅ¿s, if we had well conÅ¿idered it) not by Monarchy alone, but by AriÅ¿tocracie, and Democracie: Therefore, without all three, our Laws are diÅ¿Å¿olved, and we fall into Anarchy. Is Peace ever to be looked for without Law? If the Sword be our Law-giver, Å¿hall we not become AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inates and Heathens? Where will Truth and Religion be? Without them, farewel Peace. We feel with Å¿orrow and Å¿mart, that Inter Arma Å¿ilent Leges. And if there be neither King, Law, nor Religion, What will become of Parliaments? Our caÅ¿e will be the Å¿ame with the IÅ¿raelites, when they had no King: Every deÅ¿perate man will dare to Å¿ay to a Parliament-man, as an injurious Hebrew Å¿aid to MoÅ¿es, Who made thee a man of Authority, or Judge over us? But is there go balm left in Gilead? Is there not one man left, who by grave and Å¿eaÅ¿onable counÅ¿el might
diÅ¿cover the Incendiaries of our DiviÅ¿ions, and the Contrivers of our Factions and DiÅ¿tractions; and Å¿o divert the Deluge of ConfuÅ¿ion and Slaughter ready to overwhelm our Nation?

sp.speaker: Democritus.
sp.p: It is daily done by zealous Preachers of God's Word in the Pulpit, and by them and others in Printed Papers, with Å¿olid and weighty Motives; but with little effect: For moÅ¿t mens hearts are hardened, and their underÅ¿tandings Å¿tupified: God hath Å¿tricken us, but we have not Å¿orrowed; he hath conÅ¿umed us, but we have refuÅ¿ed to receive correction: we have made our faces harder then a Å¿tone, and have refuÅ¿ed to return. We may now, with Jeremiah the Prophet, in his fifth Chapter, Run to and fro in the Å¿treets of our EngliÅ¿h JeruÅ¿alem, and behold now, and know, and enquire in the open places thereof, if we can finde a man, or if there be any that Å¿pontaneouÅ¿ly executeth judgement, and Å¿eeketh the truth; and then hope that the Lord will Å¿pare the Land. Where is the man, who payeth his Vows to God? Where is the Patriot of his Country, fearing God and hating CovetouÅ¿neÅ¿s? Where is the JuÅ¿ticiary? Do we not Å¿ee almoÅ¿t every mans Self to be his own Country? Many great men Å¿ay, they know the way of the Lord, and the judgement of their God; but theÅ¿e have altogether broken the yoke, and burÅ¿t the bonds. The Å¿ins for which moÅ¿t often and moÅ¿t Å¿everely God puniÅ¿hed the IÅ¿raelites, were Idolatry, breach of Covenant, and Perjury. Did God puniÅ¿h them for thoÅ¿e Å¿ins, and can other Nations, now in being, hope to be quit, and go free? We expected an iÅ¿Å¿ue of our miÅ¿eries by the Sword; but they are augmented, and aggravated: our hopes fail us. What will become of that People in the end, which repoÅ¿e confidence in their own Å¿trength of Charets, HorÅ¿e-men, and HorÅ¿es? Jeremiah (in his 31 Chap. verÅ¿. 1.) telleth them what attendeth them. God is the God of Order, and not of ConfuÅ¿ion. Will not the Lord viÅ¿it for theÅ¿e things? Shall he not be avenged on Å¿uch a Nation?

sp.speaker: Heraclitus.
sp.p:
The conÅ¿ideration of theÅ¿e things, draweth a flood of tears from me. For it is moÅ¿t manifeÅ¿t, that the EngliÅ¿h JeÅ¿uites, by
their Å¿ecret and admirable policies, and Å¿ubtil inÅ¿inuations, under pretext of Tender ConÅ¿cience their Bugbear, work upon the eaÅ¿ie mindes of the weaker Å¿ort of people, who, by how much they are more Å¿hallow in Judgement, by Å¿o much are more obÅ¿tinate and Å¿tiff in Opinion, impenetrable, and inflexible with any Arguments whatÅ¿oever, Humane or Divine. AmidÅ¿t my Å¿ad and doleful tears, I am the more aÅ¿toniÅ¿hed, when I revolve this verÅ¿e predicted of England long Å¿ince, viz. Corruet Anglorum gens fraude Å¿uorum; which word Å¿uorum can have relation to, or dependance on no words in the whole Å¿eries of the Latine nouns but to one or two ending thus, viz.âituumâªâitiorum. It irketh me very grievouÅ¿ly, that it Å¿hould be Å¿aid to Å¿ome of thoÅ¿e, to whom belongeth the heading of thoÅ¿e two imperfect words, whoÅ¿e hearts are right for Church and Country, againÅ¿t all obÅ¿tructions, that exitus will be exitium: but as touching any amongÅ¿t them, who are inveterate, rancorous, and deadly enemies to the tranquillity, peace, and Å¿plendor of our National Church, and Commonwealth; I Å¿ay, Let God ariÅ¿e, and let his enemies be Å¿cattered! How Å¿hall God's wrathful indignation be appeaÅ¿ed, when through hardneÅ¿s of heart we are inÅ¿enÅ¿ible of the National Å¿in, as heinous as the Å¿in of Achan, and the bloody Å¿in of Saul againÅ¿t the Gibeonites, committed under pretence of zeal to his Nation, provoking God's wrath againÅ¿t the IÅ¿raelites to deÅ¿troy them with Famine; which was not abated, until, through David's Å¿atisfaction given to the Gibeonites, by the decollation and Å¿laughter of Saul's Å¿ons, God's wrath was appeaÅ¿ed? as 2 Sam. 21. 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8âª 9, 14. Hath not God viÅ¿ited our Nation with the Å¿ame puniÅ¿hment? It hath been Å¿aid of old, Quos Jupiter perdere vult, priÃ¹s dementat. What hope have we to evade and eÅ¿cape the Å¿nares of the politick JeÅ¿uites, when we are already wrapped and involved in them, and when we neither do nor will diÅ¿cern their moÅ¿t exquiÅ¿ite, Å¿ubtil, and cloÅ¿e conveyances? they having adopted, or rather begotten a baÅ¿tard-breed of Å¿ons, and infuÅ¿ed Å¿o much of their virulent vertue into them, that thereby they have not onely wrought weak judgements to pretended conÅ¿cience of an Independent Church, but have alÅ¿o by State-policie benummed, blinded, beÅ¿otted, and
Å¿tupified Å¿ome great and wiÅ¿e ones in our Nation, inducing them to connive at their frauds and juglings, whereby more Å¿trenuouÅ¿ly a Toleration of SchiÅ¿m and HereÅ¿ie is creeping in, then ever could have been brought in by themÅ¿elves alone for their party.

sp.speaker: Democritus.
sp.p: Charitable and pitiful Heraclitus, thy tears verily proceed from a tender conÅ¿cience affected with the abominable Å¿infulneÅ¿s of thine own Nation, and the blindneÅ¿s and Å¿tupidity thereof. But be thou not Å¿ollicitous and grieved, Å¿ince God, for horrid and loud-crying Å¿ins, hath deÅ¿igned our Nation to woful Calamities: Let us be rather comforted, and give glory to God, and rejoyce, that he hath given us the Å¿ight of thoÅ¿e things in his holy Word, which neither mighty men, nor noble, nor learned, nor Politicians will take notice of; but do rather wink with their eyes, and Å¿hut their underÅ¿tandings from being advertiÅ¿ed thereof, and will deride both thee and me for our diÅ¿courÅ¿e, if they Å¿hould hear it.

sp.speaker: Heraclitus.
sp.p: NevertheleÅ¿s, dear Democritus, let us not â¢â¢â¦ iÅ¿t: A word Å¿poken in its place is like apples of gold with pictures of Å¿ilver, as Solomon hath it in his Proverbs.

sp.speaker: Democritus.
sp.p:
MoÅ¿es and the Prophets Å¿peak plain enough to our Nation: if we will not hear them, neither will we hear, though one riÅ¿e from the dead again, unleÅ¿s he Å¿hould beat wit into our heads with a maul: and Å¿ome Å¿uch dreadful judgement, I fear, doth attend us. Were our words acceptable, or might they be profitable to our Nation, I could be inceÅ¿Å¿ant and indefatigable: for, Cuique probo Patria Å¿ua eÅ¿t jucundiÅ¿Å¿ima. But our Nation is become Å¿o barbarous and heatheniÅ¿h, that it laboureth with all its wiÅ¿dom, wealth, and power to deÅ¿troy it Å¿elf. We do but Å¿catter our words, we do but charm a deaf adder. I have lately read theÅ¿e words in a book publiÅ¿hed long before our diÅ¿tractions grew to this immenÅ¿e multiplicity (as now they are) and irreconciliable incompoÅ¿edneÅ¿s, viz. [Be wiÅ¿e, O England, and diÅ¿cern the JeÅ¿uitical RomiÅ¿h frauds, and pernitious plots, and break and avoid their laÅ¿t arrow of Independencie and AriÅ¿tocracie, (for they have no more left to wound Great Britain withal) and
be happie: Sin minus, caveto tibi, ne faciem tuam obfuÅ¿cent tenebrae non niÅ¿i ex nova Romana caligine illuminatae:] and I well know that they came to the view of Å¿ome both great and wiÅ¿e; but they Å¿eemed to them ridiculous: yet now they may Å¿ee, that darkneÅ¿s muÅ¿t give light, or we muÅ¿t have no light. The unwarrantable predictions of uncertain AÅ¿trologie promiÅ¿ing Å¿ecurity, were and are pleaÅ¿ing, and embraced; which to confide in, is as to conÅ¿ult with the witch of Endor: But the warrantable preÅ¿ages couched in the infallible Prophecies of God's holy Seers, contained in his Å¿acred Word, contemned, Å¿lighted, and rejected, even of mighty men, much more of men of inferiour order. Railing, lying, futile, Å¿currilous, Å¿editious, libellous, traiterous Pamphlets, Å¿pread abroad with all advantage by nimble winged Mercuries, have been, and are (a time very unfit for Å¿uch fopperies and iniquities, when our Nation is bleeding, languiÅ¿hing, and at the point to be extinct) embraced by moÅ¿t men, according to their Å¿everal fancies and affections, very few men having â¢â¢â¦ rned the CatechiÅ¿m of that moÅ¿t pious and venerable Doctor JoÅ¿hua Hall Å¿ometimes BiÅ¿hop of Exceter, Å¿ince BiÅ¿hop of Norwich, where they may learn how God doth and will do all things in this world, and as few having compunction of heart for the deÅ¿truction and deÅ¿olation of their own Country.

sp.speaker: Heraclitus.
sp.p: How cometh it to paÅ¿s that the JeÅ¿uites have Å¿uch influence upon our Nation now at this time, Å¿ince their manifold, bloody, and traiterous practices thorowout the whole Reign of Queen Elizabeth, of King James, of our late King Charles, are freÅ¿h in memory, being to be read in HiÅ¿tories, rehearÅ¿ed in Almanacks, and brought to our ears by publike ThankÅ¿givings to God yeerly for our deliverances from them?

sp.speaker: Democritus.
sp.p:
Thou knoweÅ¿t, Heraclitus, that a Ship at Sea is in the power of its Pilot, and that he, if out of treachery he intend it, can betray it to an enemy at his pleaÅ¿ure. The politick practices and treaÅ¿ons of the JeÅ¿uites againÅ¿t Queen Elizabethâª by commotions, rebellions, piÅ¿tols, poiÅ¿ons, poniards, the SpaniÅ¿h Armado,
were Å¿o exquiÅ¿ite and admirable, carried on with Å¿uch Å¿ecrecie, that had any of them prevailed, England muÅ¿t have gone to Rome again for the Popes pardon. But what were all thoÅ¿e their devices to that tranÅ¿cendent hyperbolical Gunpowder-treaÅ¿on, which with one Sulphureous blaÅ¿t had deÅ¿troyed King James, and all his Royal IÅ¿Å¿ue male; all the Nobility, and a great part of the Gentry, and had Å¿ubverted Religion, and our Laws, and had Å¿ubjugated our Nation again to the yoke and tyranny of the Popedom? Since then, far more tranÅ¿cendent, exact politick, never to be parallelled have their Å¿tratagems been to undermine our Church and State, by inÅ¿inuating, creeping, and Å¿erewing themÅ¿elves into eminent places and employments in both, under pretext of Patriarchacie and Sanctimony; and they have Å¿o hoodwinked many of the wiÅ¿emen in our Nation, that they Å¿uÅ¿pect them not at all, much leÅ¿s that they have now any Plot upon our Nation and Church, or are at the Rudder; but Å¿uppoÅ¿e that they Å¿it Å¿till and quiet, neither acting nor plotting any thing. It it is evident to all honeÅ¿t intelligent men, that our late Civile bellum EpiÅ¿copale was plotted and contrived by their ingenuous and profound policies; and it will Å¿hortly be as evident, that our Civile bellum Populare is driven on by their cloÅ¿e conveyances, and ambodexter-juglings, by miÅ¿leading the people under pretence of New Lights, and Divine Raptures, and ChriÅ¿tian Liberty, and Liberty of Chiveril ConÅ¿cience.

sp.speaker: Heraclitus.
sp.p:
We know well in former times the BiÅ¿hops days, when all Functions EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿tical and Civil were tranÅ¿acted and conferred at a price (for Quid mihi dabis?) it was an eaÅ¿ie thing, they being Å¿o exquiÅ¿ite and Å¿ecret in their Plots and Contrivements, and they having at that time ducem venerii caÅ¿tri, the Buck with the gilded horns for their Patron and Advocate, to Å¿tep intoâª neÅ¿tle, and rivet themÅ¿elves as well into high and eminent places in the Court, as alÅ¿o into Å¿ubordinate Judicatory-adminiÅ¿trations, and into the Clergie and Prelacie without controulment, eÅ¿pecially after the Eagles Chicken had neÅ¿ted himÅ¿elf in the higheÅ¿t Rochet in the Realm. But by what means now do they poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿s themÅ¿elves of Publike Places either EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿tical or Civil, Å¿ance there
hath uÅ¿ually been Å¿uch a wide and oppoÅ¿ite antipathy between them, and all manner of ProteÅ¿tants, though Sectaries and SeparatiÅ¿ts?

sp.speaker: Democritus.
sp.p: FirÅ¿t, know, Heraclitus, that the range and rabble of thoÅ¿e Gleeds which the Eagles prime Chicken brought in, are not outed of the Clergie, Academies, and other publike Societies, nor, as the caÅ¿e now Å¿tandeth, can be, but rather more are gotten into them. And next know, that the JeÅ¿uites are the moÅ¿t Å¿ubtil expert, and artificial ImpoÅ¿tors in the world, inÅ¿tructed by art and exerciÅ¿e, to put on Proteus Å¿hapes, and to perÅ¿onate all degrees and qualities of men, and neatly, cloÅ¿ely, and dexterouÅ¿ly to act in all manner of Societies, Councels, and Factions. And all moderate men know, and of that part yeeld, that in the late Wars many of them became Commanders and prime Officers in the Field and Forts againÅ¿t the Parliament. And if after their Å¿urrenders, and yeelding up of Forts and Forces, they have been entertained, and ma â¢â¢ Commanders in the preÅ¿ent Army, have they not obtained their ends to agitate their deÅ¿ignes of poiÅ¿oning the Army, and conÅ¿equently the whole Nation with SchiÅ¿m and HereÅ¿ie, Å¿o to hinder the Å¿ettlement of Peace, and to embroil the Nation in future War? And further, know, Heraclitus that the Pope, and his emiÅ¿Å¿aries and miniÅ¿ters have of late yeers had private Oathes for Secrecie, Fidelity, and Activity in their Catholike CauÅ¿e, to miniÅ¿ter to all their party both abroad and at home, with diÅ¿penÅ¿ation to repair to our Temples, whereby they might Å¿eem ProteÅ¿tants, Å¿o to gain popular eÅ¿teem in their Country. And Å¿ince many men have been preÅ¿ented to the Parliament from Counties and Boroughs by the power of the Souldiery, might not Å¿uch men, having taken Å¿uch Oath, by inÅ¿inuation with the Souldiery by the aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance of their party in the Army, make themÅ¿elves of the number of LegiÅ¿latores, that they might without the leaÅ¿t jealouÅ¿ie or Å¿uÅ¿pect become LegiÅ¿violatores?
sp.q: An EngliÅ¿h man Italianate, a devil incarnate.

sp.speaker: Heraclitus.
sp.p:
What is thine expectation, Democritus? DoÅ¿t thou conclude
that theÅ¿e Foxes, Wolves, and wilde Boars Å¿hall Å¿till prevail againÅ¿t the unity of the Church, and tranquillity of the Realm?

sp.speaker: Democritus.
sp.p: Though I know well, that Hoc rupti Foederis deaurabit aquila, that his HolineÅ¿s is better pleaÅ¿ed with the Device and Plot of his deareÅ¿t Å¿ons the JeÅ¿uites for Democracie, then Apes with nuts: if their Plot take full effect, he will write both in red letters in his Kalendar. Yet I make no Å¿uch concluÅ¿ion; but I conclude them to be the Å¿ervants of God, as Nebuchadnezzar and Pharaoh were, and as the devil Å¿ometimes is, that is, inÅ¿truments to execute his vengeance, to bring inevitable wo upon our Nation, and for his glory to gather wholeÅ¿om Hellebore out of the Orcades, therewith to purge our Nation of Phrenzie and HypocriÅ¿ie, and the Church of SchiÅ¿m, HereÅ¿ie, and Idolatry; and thence and thereout alÅ¿o to gather a luÅ¿ty new green BeÅ¿om, that Å¿hall Å¿weep themÅ¿elves, and all their Å¿purious Å¿eed, and baÅ¿tard-Å¿ons out of the Realm againÅ¿t their wills. And I conclude the JeÅ¿uites to be thoÅ¿e unclean Å¿pirits, like Frogs â¢ oming out of the mouth of the Dragon, and out of the mouth of the BeaÅ¿t, and out of the mouth of the FalÅ¿e Prophet: for they are the Å¿pirits of devils working miracles, to go unto the Kings of the earth, and of the whole world, to gather them to the battel of the great day of God Almighty, mentioned in Rev. 16. 13, 14.
Let honeÅ¿t men therefore, with David, tarry the Lord's leaÅ¿ure, be Å¿trong, and truÅ¿t in the Lord, and their hearts Å¿hall be comforted.

And as Lot was in Sodom, if they be captivated, let them hope that God will Å¿end an Abraham to deliver them. And let them reÅ¿olve with David, that whoÅ¿e dwelleth under the defence of the moÅ¿t High, Å¿hall abide in the Å¿hadow of the Almighty.

div.head: To England, An Anagram on ENGLAND.

lg.l: ENGLAND, lament, repent; bitter Ennd-gal,
Thine Anagram portends thy fatal fal:
Like SamÅ¿on, grinding with thine eyes put out,
Thou driveÅ¿t JeÅ¿uites deÅ¿ignes about:
Thou mak'Å¿t them Å¿port; they make thee dearly pay
For thine own downfal, ruine, and decay.
No help remains, but to retort their darts
Upon ThemÅ¿elves, Å¿hot at good men and Arts.
WiÅ¿ely diÅ¿cern; be not blinde, Å¿tupid, dull,
In Å¿uff'ring them with Shadows thee to gull,
Under pretence ChriÅ¿t's GoÅ¿pel to advance,
To advance HereÅ¿ie, SchiÅ¿m, Ignorance;
By falÅ¿e pretext BeaÅ¿ts Language to drive hence,
To gain BeaÅ¿t far more Å¿way then Peter-pence.
HadÅ¿t thou in time impos'd th' Abjuring Oath,
They had not poiÅ¿on'd thee with deadly Broath:
But now they have enjoyn'd thee Å¿uch a diet
Will gar thee pine, it's vain to be unquiet.
No joy remains, but by Gods Word to know,
He will at laÅ¿t his Rod in fier throw.
